name: Protein S Deficiency
description: Inherited or acquired deficiency of protein S, a vitamin K-dependent cofactor for activated protein C. Functions as the essential cofactor for APC-mediated inactivation of factors Va and VIIIa.

pathophysiology.mechanism: Protein S serves as cofactor for activated protein C. Also has APC-independent anticoagulant activity via direct inhibition of factor Xa and factor IXa

protein_forms.total_protein_s: Sum of free and bound forms

types.description: Quantitative deficiency - reduced total and free protein S
types.labs: Low total, low free, low activity

types.description: Qualitative deficiency - normal antigen, reduced activity
types.labs: Normal total, normal free, low activity
Normal total, low free, low activity

clinical_features.warfarin_skin_necrosis: Can occur, similar mechanism to protein C deficiency

pregnancy_considerations.physiologic_decrease: Protein S levels decrease 30-40% during normal pregnancy
pregnancy_considerations.testing_timing: Avoid testing during pregnancy or postpartum

interpretation.deficiency: <60% free protein S on two occasions

confounders: Acute inflammation (C4b-BP is acute phase reactant)
diagnosis.testing_timing: Wait 2-4 weeks after stopping warfarin, avoid pregnancy/postpartum

management.acute_vte: Standard anticoagulation with heparin bridging to warfarin

pregnancy_management.prophylaxis: LMWH throughout pregnancy for high-risk patients

clinical_pearls: Free protein S is the functional form - always measure free, not just total
Pregnancy causes 30-40% physiologic decrease in protein S - do not diagnose deficiency during pregnancy
C4b-binding protein is an acute phase reactant - inflammation causes functional protein S deficiency
learning_objectives: Distinguish between total and free protein S and their clinical significance
Identify conditions that cause acquired protein S deficiency
Describe appropriate timing for protein S testing

citations.source: Harrison's Principles of Internal Medicine, 21st ed. McGraw-Hill.
